Title:
A phylogeny of Delphinieae (Ranunculaceae) shows that
Aconitum is nested within Delphinium and that Late Miocene transitions
to long life cycles in the Himalayas and South West China coincide with
bursts in diversification
Keywords:
Beringia, life cycle evolution, Mediterranean, molecular
clock, paraphyly, Tibetan Plateau
Abstract:
The tribe Delphinieae (Ranunculaceae) comprises two
species-rich genera, Aconitum and Delphinium, the latter including
Consolida and Aconitella. The 650-700 species are distributed in Eurasia
and North America; exceptions are three species on the tropical African
Mts. Maximum likelihood analyses of 2088 aligned nucleotides of plastid
and nuclear sequences obtained from 188 accessions of Delphinieae from
throughout the geographic range (plus relevant outgroups) show that
Aconitum is nested within Delphinium and that three short-lived (annual
or biennial) Mediterranean species belonging to Delphinium subgenus
Staphisagria are the sister clade to all other Delphinieae. Ancestral
state reconstructions and molecular clock dating imply that the Early
Oligocene ancestor of the mostly perennial Delphinieae was an annual or
a biennial. Via the Beringian corridor, Aconitum entered North America
c. 3.3 Ma ago and Delphinium c. 2.9 Ma ago; Delphinium also reached the
East African Mts. at 2.4 Ma ago, during the major uplift experienced by
the East African Rift system. Late Miocene bursts in diversification
rates in the Himalayan and South-Western Chinese clades of Aconitum and
Delphinium are associated with transitions from annual to perennial or
pseudo-annual growth.
